question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
If the digit represented by $\triangle$ satisfies the following addition problem $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 3 & 2 & 1 & \triangle_6\\ & & & \triangle & 4 & 0_6\\ &+ & & & \triangle & 2_6\\ \cline{2-6} & & 4 & 2 & \triangle & 1_6\\ \end{array} $$what is the value of $\triangle$?
inference:
In order to determine the value of $\triangle$, we will start by calculating the last column. $$\begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 3 & 2 & 1 & \triangle_6\\ & & & \triangle & 4 & 0_6\\ &+ & & & \triangle & 2_6\\ \cline{2-6} & & 4 & 2 & \triangle & 1_6\\ \end{array} $$
$$0_6 + 2_6 = 2$$
$$2+ \triangle = 10 \rightarrow  \triangle = \boxed{4}$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{4}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: We notice that in the units column, it's impossible for $\triangle+2=1_6$. So, it must be the case that $\triangle+2=11_6=7$. That would mean $\triangle=7-2=\boxed{5}$. We can check that our answer works by plugging our value for triangle into the original problem: $$ \begin{array}{c@{}c@{\;}c@{}c@{}c@{}c} & & 3 & 2 & 1 & 5_6\\ & & & 5 & 4 & 0_6\\ &+ & & & 5 & 2_6\\ \cline{2-6} & & 4 & 2 & 5 & 1_6.\\ \end{array} $$The addition problem still works, so our answer is correct.
